Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: I was walking down the street with my younger brother, keeping an eye on him like Mom always asked. Suddenly, he darted toward the curb, not even glancing at the cars. My heart jumped, and I reached out, ready to pull him back, knowing I had to keep him safe no matter what. Just then, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my best friend, Sam. I answered, and his voice was shaky—he was clearly upset, asking if I could talk. He needed me to listen, to be there for him like I always promised. But my brother was already stepping off the curb, and I could see a car coming. I felt torn in two—my brother needed me to protect him, but Sam needed me to listen and care. My mind raced, caught between the urge to shout at my brother and the need to comfort my friend, both expecting me to be there for them in completely different ways at the exact same moment.
